clients/api.title: Ampache API Clients
clients/api.description: A list of clients that use the Ampache API

clients/clients.title: Clients
clients/clients.description: Ampache runs on a web interface allowing you to play media directly from your web browser. See the Web Interface page for more information.

clients/demo-server.title: demo.ampache.dev
clients/demo-server.description: The official Ampache demo server is now up and running!

configuration/acl.title: Access Control Lists
configuration/acl.description: Ampache supports internal Access Control Lists, these are IP/DNS based restrictions on different actions and interactions with Ampache. By Default Access Controls lists are turned off in Ampache. In order to turn them on you must modify the /config/ampache.cfg.php and set access_control to true

configuration/Ampache-Icecast-and-Liquid.title: Ampache + Icecast&Liquidsoap
configuration/Ampache-Icecast-and-Liquid.description: Channels suck, I can't fix them without taking a lot of time for something that is already done better elsewhere.

configuration/api.title: Ampache API
configuration/api.description: Ampache has an open, published API that can allow 3rd party applications to integrate with the music, meta-data, and album art held by Ampache. The primary use for this API is to expose your Ampache server to mobile devices while maintaining a native and fully functional client without having to rely on a web browser. Full documentation for developers on Ampache's API can be found at ampache.org

configuration/broadcasts.title: Broadcasts
configuration/broadcasts.description: Broadcast what you're currently playing in your web player to other users.

configuration/catalog-filters.title: Private Catalogs
configuration/catalog-filters.description: Want to organize catalogs so your kids can't hear your music or your wife can safely avoid Malaysian Gore-Grind?

configuration/cron.title: Speed up Ampache using cron
configuration/cron.description: A common complaint is that Ampache can be slow! Lets look at making that a things of the past!

configuration/democratic.title: Democratic Play
configuration/democratic.description: Democratic Play is a communal vote-based playlist feature. It is meant to be used in situations where you have many users and a single output source. Some examples would be an office with a central stereo or a bar / club. There are two types of users on a democratic playlist. Voters and Admins. Voters can only add/remove their votes to/from the playlist. They are only allowed one vote per trac. Admins have all the same rights except they can also completely remove a song from the playlist. All democratic playlists also have a Base Playlist. The base playlist is what is used when there are no voted songs. Once a song has been played via democratic play it is removed from the playlist.

configuration/localplay/HttpQ.title: HttpQ Localplay
configuration/localplay/HttpQ.description: HttpQ is a protocol for remote controlling a music player over a network. You can use this if you, say, have a server which is plugged into your stereo. If you use a music player that supports HttpQ (e.g. Winamp or foobar2000) you can control the music player remotely from another machine, e.g. your laptop. You should have Ampache installed on the server machine and your music player. Then you log on and use Localplay to control the server. BrowseAmp is another example of this.

configuration/localplay/localplay.title: Localplay
configuration/localplay/localplay.description: Ampache has the ability to remote control 3rd party programs through the web interface. Localplay works on the principle of a Controller written by someone and placed in your /modules/localplay directory and then individual Instances of a given Localplay Controller. Each instance has its own distinct settings, owner and permissions.

configuration/localplay/Localplay-API.title: Localplay API
configuration/localplay/Localplay-API.description: All controllers and config files are located in /modules/localplay/ they are named with the following conventions. [name of service].controller.php and [name of service].cfg.php. For example if you are using MPD then the names would be mpd.controller.php and mpd.cfg.php The class inside must be Ampache[name of service] in order to avoid conflicts and must extend the localplay_controller class

configuration/localplay/mpd.title: Configuring MPD for Localplay
configuration/localplay/mpd.description: Ampache has the ability to remote control an MPD instance over the network. MPD or Music Player Daemon is designed for integrating a computer into a stereo system that provides control for music playback over a local network. this document will walk you through the steps on how to setup localplay with MPD. It is assumed that you have Admin rights on your Ampache instance.

configuration/localplay/MPD-With-ALSA-Co.title: Sample MPD config file
configuration/localplay/MPD-With-ALSA-Co.description: This is a sample config for using Alsa and MPD on a Raspeberry P3 or P4.   This conjuration Allows correction of those who might have song that will not play with MPD but fine whit Gnome which is good to use for testing MPD..

configuration/localplay/Sample-Config-Wi.title: Sample MPD config file
configuration/localplay/Sample-Config-Wi.description: This is a sample config for ALSA and Raspberry.  The settings in this file allow for you to use Gnome music player for single song testing of your catalog without and interaction of Ampache trying to modify the stream output. It only does a Replay gain.  This Should help with those who have problems with songs skipping and not being able to control the player.

configuration/localplay/Sample-MPD-Confi.title: Sample MPD config file
configuration/localplay/Sample-MPD-Confi.description: This is a sample config for ALSA and Raspberry. The settings in this file allow for you to use Gnome music player for single song testing of your catalog without and interaction of Ampache trying to modify the stream output. It only does a Replay gain. This Should help with those who have problems with songs skipping and not being able to control the player.

configuration/localplay/Upnp.title: Upnp Localplay
configuration/localplay/Upnp.description: Upnp is a protocol for remote controlling a music/video player over a network. Commonly it's found in TVs network media players and software like Kodi. If you use a controller like BubbleUPnP you can control the renderer remotely.

configuration/localplay/VLC.title: Configuring VLC for Localplay
configuration/localplay/VLC.description: Ampache has the ability to remote control VLC over the network via it's http interface. VLC or VLC media player is a cross-platform open source media player that can play most known media formats. This document will walk you through the steps on how to setup localplay with VLC. It is assumed that you have Admin rights on your Ampache instance.

configuration/multi-artist.title: Ampache with Multi Artist support
configuration/multi-artist.description: Ampache 5.3.0 includes support for connecting multiple artist objects to a single song or album.

configuration/remote-catalogs.title: Ampache Remote Catalogs
configuration/remote-catalogs.description: You can remotely connect one more Ampache servers to one or more other Ampache servers. This is accomplished using API-RPC. The below documentation will walk you through configuring two Ampache installs and connecting one to the other. This functionality is disabled by default.

configuration/services.title: Ampache API
configuration/services.description: Ampache has an open, published API that can allow 3rd party applications to integrate with the music, meta-data, and album art held by Ampache. The primary use for this API is to expose your Ampache server to mobile devices while maintaining a native and fully functional client without having to rely on a web browser. Full documentation for developers on Ampache's API can be found at ampache.org

configuration/subsonic.title: SubSonic API
configuration/subsonic.description: Your Ampache server can be accessed through the SubSonic API.

configuration/transcoding/Transcode-Cach.title: What is Transcode Caching
configuration/transcoding/Transcode-Cach.description: Managing your files can be complicated; trancoding helps smooth out the experience by converting your files on demand into preset types and bit rates. It's also useful when you have a file format that's massive like a wav file, a type that's incompatible with your chosen player or an application that can't support your chosen format.

configuration/transcoding/transcoding.title: Transcoding
configuration/transcoding/transcoding.description: Transcoding allows you to convert one type of file to another. Ampache supports on the fly transcoding of all file types based on user, IP address or available bandwidth. In order to transcode Ampache takes advantage of existing binary applications such as ffmpeg, Lame or mp3splt. In order for transcoding to work you must first install the supporting applications and ensure that they are executable by the webserver. If you have any trouble to get transcoding working you can also have a look here.

development/Branch-Layout.title: Ampache Branch Layouts
development/Branch-Layout.description: To help structure code a bit better Ampache has split repo activity into the following types

help/import-lastfm-data.description: Before I started really using Ampache I scrobbled. I had years of information kept in Last.FM and that data is really important.

information/ampache-use-cases.title: Ampache Use Cases
information/ampache-use-cases.description: This page describes some of the various tasks that Ampache accomplish. It will define why and how these tasks behave and can be accomplished within Ampache. If your particular use case isn't listed here, feel free to submit a Feature Request). What you want to do may already be possible, and is just waiting to be written on this page.

information/TV-Shows-and-Movies.title: TV Shows and Movies
information/TV-Shows-and-Movies.description: The Ampache file parser for TV show and movie names is based partially on Kodi specs. The details can be found at kodi.wiki TVshows and kodi.wiki Movies.  However, it will not automatically apply names and other values without the correct information.  Applying MP4 tags to files before adding them to the Ampache catalog is recommended.  Using the command line tool `mp4tags`, this can be done manually (file-by-file) or with the help of a script.  For example:

information/Upgrade.title: Upgrade
information/Upgrade.description: As an assumption we assume you know the path to your Ampache folder and how to manage your permissions.

information/Web-Interface.title: Standard Web Interface
information/Web-Interface.description: The standard interface is a web-based graphical user interface available via web browsers. It enables the user to search and browse media, playback media, construct random or custom playlists, make changes to options, and administer the server.

information/Web-Player.title: Web Player
information/Web-Player.description: The default player for the Web Interface is the Web Player. For your convenience or when you are on move, you can listen to music without additional software other than your web browser. If it's not currently enabled, you can set it by clicking the drop-down menu on the top-right corner of any page, and selecting "Web Player".

information/which-zip.description: Ampache supports a lot of different install options.

plugins/plugins.title: Ampache Plugins
plugins/plugins.description: Ampache contains a number of plugins that are included with each install.

plugins/writing-plugins.title: Ampache Plugins
plugins/writing-plugins.description: Plugins are placed in modules/plugins; the name of the file must be "./Name/Name.plugin.php". e.g. Dummy/Dummy.plugin.php.

themes/themes.title: Themes
themes/themes.description: Ampache has an integrated theme system that allows users to modify the CSS/images and can be configured on a per user basis. Official themes are available under the /themes directory.
